TopicTitle: Should I put KSP on my resume? (sorry if wrong forum)

Articles.Content: I'm applying to become a rocket scientist at Alliant Techsystems. Should I put KSP on the "related interests" section of my applicaton, or not?

personally I wouldn't, but might include something generic like "science related computer programs"

games and gamers still don't really have a good reputation among older generations.
Yeah, something like KSP sounds more like something you might casually mention during the interview.
Maybe bring it up casually during the interview, but it just seems terribly unprofessional to put "I played a video game" on a resume, no matter how applicable it is.

I don't want to brag, but... I've landed on Tylo.

*crowd gasps*

... at night.

*woman screams*

... on IVA.

*old person faints*

I think personally if it was for a related career I would. If you have a degree in astrophysics or years of experience in engineering or whatever, that's your main credential, KSP is just a bit extra. Shows that you're interested in this stuff beyond just wanting a job in it. If KSP is your only real rocket science credential then the job application is a long shot but you need it there.

The only way I can see it being counted against you is if it's the only thing in the general interests/hobbies section. In that case I'd probably leave such a section out altogether, it's frankly not all that important.
I wouldn't mention it at all unless something related comes up in the interview.
Old people distrust computer games, even computers themselves. And they hold most power in corporations. So do not mention games in resume at all.

KSP is not a "related interest".

KSP is more than an ellegant hobby. Well for some of us kind of a lifestile. For others... Did you hear about this Scott Manley guy?

Maybe bring it up casually during the interview, but it just seems terribly unprofessional to put "I played a video game" on a resume, no matter how applicable it is.

The one situation where this is okay is if you're applying to a video game company. When I got my job at Blizzard (and got laid off 6 months later ), it definitely helped that I played their games religiously. In fact, most of the interviews were about my gaming experience.

But for jobs in the real world, video game knowledge isn't really well-looked-upon.
Also, don't forget to put kerbal merits insignia on your tunic.
